Question_1.Context: The study focused on engineering whole cell systems with co-display of adhesive proteins and PETase for PET biodegradation. The efficiency of PET degradation was compared between different systems.
Question_1.Question: What was the major hydrolytic product observed when using free Fast-PETase for PET degradation?
Question_1.Source: When we used free Fast-PETase for PET degradation, MHET accounted for the largest proportion (over 90%) of all degradation products (BHET, MHET and TPA), which is consistent with literatures that another MHETase should be involved in the hydrolysis of MHET.

Question_2.Context: The study investigated the adhesion ability of engineered E. coli cells displaying different adhesive proteins on PET surfaces.
Question_2.Question: Which marine organism-derived adhesive protein showed a 50% increase in adhesion ability compared to E. coli cells without adhesive proteins?
Question_2.Source: Compared to E. coli cells without adhesive proteins, the display of mfp-3 showed a 50% increase of adhering cell number.

Question_3.Context: The study compared the PET degradation efficiency of E. coli cells solely displaying Fast-PETase and those co-displaying adhesive proteins and Fast-PETase.
Question_3.Question: Which system showed the highest PET degradation rate of over 15% within 24 hours?
Question_3.A: E. coli cells solely displaying Fast-PETase
Question_3.D: All systems showed the same degradation rate
Question_3.Source: The PET degradation rate of co-display-mfp in 24 h exceeded 15%, which was twofold more than that by solely displaying Fast-PETase.

Question_4.Context: The study examined the efficiency of different anchor proteins for displaying Fast-PETase on the surfaces of E. coli cells.
Question_4.Question: Which anchor protein was found to be the best for displaying Fast-PETase based on PET degradation efficiency?
Question_4.Source: The comparison of PET degradation efficiency by three systems under the same conditions indicated that AIDA-I is the best anchor protein.

Question_5.Context: The study investigated the effect of co-displaying adhesive proteins and Fast-PETase on the surfaces of E. coli cells for PET biodegradation.
Question_5.Question: Which system showed a 2.31-fold improvement in PET degradation compared to using an equivalent amount of free Fast-PETase?
Question_5.D: All systems showed the same improvement
Question_5.Source: For the co-display strains, 57 ng or 60 ng of Fast-PETase was displayed on the surfaces for E. coli co-display-cp52k or E. coli co-display-mfp, respectively. The degradation rate of sole-display, co-sdisplay-cp52k and co-display-mfp increased by 0.45, 1.39 and 2.31-fold, respectively.

Question_6.Context: The study examined the adhesion performance of E. coli cells displaying adhesive proteins on PET surfaces.
Question_6.Question: Which adhesive protein was selected for evaluation based on its strong hydrophobic reactions with PET surfaces?
Question_6.Source: Because cp52k contains over 50% hydrophobic amino acids, this characteristic makes it possible to form strong hydrophobic reactions with PET surfaces.

Question_7.Context: The study compared the efficiency of different anchor proteins for displaying Fast-PETase on the surfaces of E. coli cells.
Question_7.Question: Which anchor protein was selected for displaying Fast-PETase based on the comparison of PET degradation efficiency among different systems?
Question_7.Source: The comparison of PET degradation efficiency by three systems under the same conditions indicated that AIDA-I is the best anchor protein.

Question_8.Context: The study examined the adhesion ability of engineered E. coli cells displaying different adhesive proteins on PET surfaces.
Question_8.Question: Which adhesive protein was known to form strong π-π and cation-π interactions with poly- styrene and polymethylmethacrylate?
Question_8.Source: mfp-3, a type of mussel adhesive protein, is known to form strong π-π and cation-π interactions with polystyrene and polymethylmethacrylate.

Question_9.Question: What was the major hydrolytic product observed when using free Fast-PETase for PET degradation?
Question_9.Source: When we used free Fast-PETase for PET degradation, MHET accounted for the largest proportion (over 90%) of all degradation products (BHET, MHET and TPA), which is consistent with literatures that another MHETase should be involved in the hydrolysis of MHET.
